topic_page.title: Skin & Cosmetic Health

intro.what_this_topic_means: This topic covers skin appearance and barrier function: wrinkles, hydration, texture, elasticity, and the difference between cosmetic effects and therapeutic claims.
common_misconceptions: Topical cosmetic ingredients are not the same as prescription dermatology treatments.
A plausible mechanism does not guarantee penetration to the target in real skin.
A short-term cosmetic effect does not prove long-term benefit or safety.
who_should_be_extra_cautious: People with severe dermatitis/eczema or compromised skin barrier
People with a history of allergic contact reactions
Pregnancy/lactation (formulation ingredients matter even if the peptide is low-risk)

how_to_use_this_page: Topics help you browse; they do not recommend peptides.
Always check status and risk score first.
Human evidence and preclinical evidence are separated.

peptides.why_people_look_it_up: Common topical cosmetic peptide discussed for expression-line appearance and 'Botox-like' marketing; outcomes depend heavily on formulation and delivery.
Popular topical 'copper peptide' discussed for skin appearance; effects depend heavily on formulation and delivery.

safety_callouts.title: Cosmetic vs therapeutic
safety_callouts.body: Many skin peptides are used in cosmetics. This does not mean they are approved drugs. Effectiveness depends heavily on formulation, delivery, concentration, and skin biology.

evidence_notes.title: Formulation matters
evidence_notes.body: For topical peptides, delivery to relevant layers of skin is a major variable. Evidence often varies by product formulation and study design.
